div.p: >> Hi. This is Joyce Farrell.

Let's take a quick look
at multi-threading.

When you run programs on a
computer with a single CPU,

you can run one process
at a time.

Typically, one process
runs, and when it's done,

a second one might
follow until it's done.
When you have multi-threading,

you can run two processes
concurrently.

For example, you might
start one process

and then while it's
waiting for something,

perhaps a second
process can run.

And while it's waiting
for something,

the first one can
take a turn again,
and so on in round robin-fashion

until both processes
are complete.

Sometimes problems arise if
you have two threads that need
to use the same resource.

For example, if there's only one
printer and both threads need

to print, one will have
to wait for the other.

Or perhaps both threads are
accessing the same database.

Assume there are two operators
selling concert seat tickets
on the telephone.

And assume the first
operator gets a call

and the caller requests
two seats.

It's checked and found that
those seats are available,
and the "holds" needs to be put

on those seats while
credit card data is checked

and the operator takes down
other data from the caller.

While they're waiting, perhaps
the second operator gets a call.

Perhaps that caller
requests one of the seats

that the first caller
has a hold on.

In that case, the seats
will be said to be locked

and the second caller will
not have access to them.

Then while the second
caller's thinking,

perhaps the first caller
will get the credit card data
and reserve those two seats.

Then maybe the second caller
will select two other seats,

and maybe one of
those is already sold
and will be rejected.

And then maybe the second caller
will select two new seats,
and maybe a hold can be put

on those while the
credit card data is taken
from the second caller.

Meanwhile, while we're waiting
to check the credit card data,
maybe the first caller decides

that they really
need a third ticket,

and perhaps they request
one where there's a hold.

That request will be
rejected, and so on.

The two processes can
be run concurrently,

sharing the same
data, if care is taken

to lock the data while
it's under processing.

That's a quick look
at multi-threading.
Thanks for watching.
